title: 114_hr5598
content: The Act may be cited as the "Plymouth 400th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the upcoming 400th anniversary of the Mayflower voyage and the founding of Plymouth Colony, highlighting the cultural contributions and traditions that shaped the United States through the interaction of the Wampanoag and English peoples. The settlers, including the Pilgrims, and the Mayflower symbolize freedom and law, while the Wampanoag's assistance and association with the Pilgrims created an important legacy. The Mayflower Compact, signed before landing in Plymouth, was a cornerstone for self-governance in the New World. Over 20 million descendants worldwide trace their ancestry back to Mayflower passengers. Plymouth 400, Inc. was established in 2009 to ensure a national observance of the Plymouth 400th anniversary. The Plymouth 400th anniversary will focus on exploration, innovation, immigration, self-governance, religious freedom, and thanksgiving. Plymouth 400, Inc. will lead efforts for a commemorative coin series and postage stamps. The commemorative coins will bring attention to Plymouth Colony's legacy and help finance related activities. The commemorative coins will support a national observance in 2020 and 2021 of the 400th anniversary of the Pilgrim landing, including the signing of the Mayflower Compact and the "First Thanksgiving" feast. People visit Plymouth to see historic sites and learn about the Pilgrims, Wampanoag people, and the Mayflower's significance. These symbols represent freedom, family, law, and justice. The commemorative coins will support a national observance in 2020 and 2021 of the 400th anniversary of the Pilgrim landing, including the signing of the Mayflower Compact and the "First Thanksgiving" feast. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the landing and settlement of Plymouth Colony, the signing of the Mayflower Compact, and the role of the indigenous Wampanoag tribes. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year of minting (2020, 2021, or 2020-2021), and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consulting with Plymouth 400, Inc. The organizations involved in the design selection process for the Plymouth Colony commemorative coins include Plymouth 400, Inc., Plimoth Plantation, Inc., Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe, Wampanoag Tribe of Gayhead (Aquinnah), General Society of Mayflower Descendants, Pilgrim Society, Plymouth Antiquarian Society, Pilgrim Monument and Provincetown Museum, Massachusetts Cultural Council, and Massachusetts Historical Society. The design will be reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single US Mint facility during a 2-year period starting January 1, 2020. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be distributed with 50% going to Plymouth 400, Inc. to support events from 2020 to 2021 and local historical preservation. Surcharges from sales of coins will be distributed as follows: 15% to local historical preservation and cultural organizations, 15% to Plimoth Plantation for maintenance efforts, 15% to a Wampanoag tribal organization for educational programs, and 10% to the General Society of Mayflower Descendants. The surcharges from sales of coins will be distributed to support the restoration of the main facility in Plymouth, fund the research library, and for educational purposes for Mayflower Descendants. Additionally, 10% of the surcharges will go to the Pilgrim Society to display the settlement story and artifacts, including the role of the Wampanoag tribe. The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the organizations receiving funds. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual 2 program issuance limitation under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
